verses.text: Then Job answered and said:
verses.comment: Job responds to Bildad’s words, beginning a speech that deals with God's justice and the challenge of approaching Him.

verses.text: Indeed, I know this is true; but how can a mortal be righteous before God?
verses.comment: Job acknowledges the universal sinfulness of mankind, a theme developed in Romans 3. The question highlights humanity's need for a mediator.

verses.text: If one wished to argue with Him, he could not answer Him once in a thousand times.
verses.comment: No one can dispute with God; His wisdom and knowledge far surpass ours.

verses.text: He is wise in heart and mighty in strength—who has hardened himself against Him and prospered?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question affirming God’s invincibility. One cannot resist Him and succeed.

verses.text: He moves mountains before they know it, overturning them in His anger.
verses.comment: Job describes God’s sovereign and immediate power. Jesus later refers to faith moving mountains in Mark 11:23.

verses.text: He shakes the earth out of its place, and its pillars tremble.
verses.comment: God's authority extends to the foundations of the natural world. The ‘pillars’ image occurs elsewhere in poetry of Scripture.

verses.text: He commands the sun, and it does not rise; He seals off the light of the stars.
verses.comment: God controls creation, as seen in the darkness of the Egyptian plagues.

verses.text: He alone stretches out the heavens and treads on the waves of the sea.
verses.comment: This foreshadows Jesus walking on water (Matt. 14:25). Only God rules the unruly sea—pointing subtly to Christ's divine nature.

verses.text: He makes the Bear, Orion, and the Pleiades, and the constellations of the south.
verses.comment: Job highlights God’s craftsmanship in the heavens, referencing constellations by ancient names.

verses.text: He does great, unsearchable things, wonders without number.
verses.comment: No one can measure all God's deeds; His mystery invites reverence and worship.

verses.text: Behold, He passes by me, and I do not see Him; He moves on, but I do not perceive Him.
verses.comment: God's ways are often hidden from us. This foreshadows humanity’s longing for an encounter with God, fulfilled in the Incarnation.

verses.text: If He snatches away, who can hinder Him? Who can say to Him, 'What are you doing?'
verses.comment: Emphasizes God’s uncontestable sovereignty—a truth echoed in both Daniel and Paul’s letters.

verses.text: God will not turn back His anger; beneath Him, the helpers of Rahab bow down.
verses.comment: ‘Rahab’ is a poetic term for chaos or pride—sometimes linked to cosmic evil. Even spiritual powers are subject to God.

verses.text: How then can I answer Him, or choose my words before Him?
verses.comment: Job’s humility prefigures the soul’s posture before God, needing grace and humility to approach the Almighty (Luke 18:13).

verses.text: Though I were righteous, I could not answer; I would pray for mercy to my Judge.
verses.comment: Job senses the need for intercession—a figure of Christ's mediating role, and the need for appeal to divine mercy.

verses.text: If I summoned Him and He answered me, I still would not believe that He was listening to my voice.
verses.comment: Job feels distant from God, showing humanity's need for assurance—in later revelation, God draws near as one who hears.

verses.text: For He crushes me with a storm and multiplies my wounds without cause.
verses.comment: Job’s suffering prefigures the Suffering Servant who endures affliction without cause (Isaiah 53).

verses.text: He will not let me catch my breath, but fills me with bitterness.
verses.comment: Bitterness and trial are themes later found in Lamentations. Yet redemptive suffering brings the soul to deeper trust.

verses.text: If it is a matter of strength, behold, He is mighty! If it is of justice, who will summon Him?
verses.comment: No one can accuse God—His strength and justice are flawless. These are echoed by St. Paul in Romans.

verses.text: Even if I were righteous, my own mouth would condemn me; If I were blameless, it would prove me perverse.
verses.comment: Points ahead to the doctrine that all have sinned and cannot justify themselves—only God can declare righteous.

verses.text: I am blameless, yet I do not know myself; I despise my life.
verses.comment: Job’s deep affliction stirs up questions of identity and self-knowledge before God. True self-understanding comes from divine light.

verses.text: It is all the same; therefore I say, He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.
verses.comment: Suffering seems indiscriminate—only later revelation clarifies its purpose in God’s redemptive plan.

verses.text: When disaster brings sudden death, He mocks at the despair of the innocent.
verses.comment: Job, in his anguish, perceives God as distant from innocent suffering—a point later clarified in the fullness of revelation.

verses.text: The earth is given into the hand of the wicked; He covers the faces of its judges—if it is not He, then who is it?
verses.comment: The problem of evil and injustice is on display—anticipating later biblical hope for a righteous Judge.

verses.text: My days are swifter than a runner; they flee away, they see no good.
verses.comment: Job laments life’s fleeting nature—a theme echoed in the Psalms.

verses.text: They pass by like reed boats, like an eagle swooping down on its prey.
verses.comment: Images of speed and transience show the brevity of human life.

verses.text: If I say, 'I will forget my complaint, I will put off my sad face and be cheerful,'
verses.comment: Despite attempts at hope, Job feels weighed down by sorrow.

verses.text: I become afraid of all my sufferings, for I know you will not hold me innocent.
verses.comment: Job fears God’s judgment, sensing that human righteousness cannot acquit. This highlights the need for God’s mercy.

verses.text: I am to be condemned—why then do I labor in vain?
verses.comment: Job’s sense of futility calls to mind the preacher’s laments in Ecclesiastes.

verses.text: If I wash myself with snow and cleanse my hands with lye,
verses.comment: Purity rituals cannot remove the reality of sin—true cleansing must come from God.

verses.text: yet you will plunge me into the pit, and even my own clothes would detest me.
verses.comment: Job feels even his best efforts are fruitless—a deep sense of human unworthiness.

verses.text: For He is not a man like me, that I might answer Him, that we might go to trial together.
verses.comment: Job desires a mediator between himself and God—a longing fulfilled when God became man to bridge the gap.

verses.text: There is no arbiter between us, who might lay his hand upon us both.
verses.comment: Job laments the absence of a mediator—a role later fulfilled uniquely in Jesus (1 Tim 2:5), who stands between God and humanity.

verses.text: Let Him take His rod away from me, and let not dread of Him terrify me.
verses.comment: Job wishes to relate to God without fear—anticipating the hope of confident relationship with God through mediation.

verses.text: Then I would speak without fear of Him, for I am not so in myself.
verses.comment: Only with a mediator can one approach God with confidence (Hebrews 4:16). Here, Job’s cry is answered in the fullness of revelation with an invitation to draw near through a divinely instituted mediator.
